title: Five-for-Seven Trolley
a1: the trolley problem is a thought experiment in ethics first introduced by philosopher philippa foot in 1967. the general form of the problem is as follows: there is a runaway trolley barreling down a track towards five workers who will be killed if the trolley proceeds on its current course. there is a switch nearby that will cause the trolley to instead diverge onto a different track where only one worker will be killed. is it morally permissible for a bystander to flip the switch and cause the trolley to kill the one worker instead of the five?  the trolley problem is intended to test our intuitions about moral responsibility and the value of human life. many people believe that it is morally permissible to flip the switch in order to save the lives of the five workers. after all, the one worker who will be killed if the switch is flipped is not responsible for the trolley being on the track in the first place, and the five workers who will be killed if the switch is not flipped are not responsible for the trolley being on the track either. furthermore, the death of one worker seems like a much lesser tragedy than the death of five workers.  however, there are also some people who believe that it is not morally permissible

title: Infanticide

The coastal route will get you to your friend's house in about three hours and fifteen minutes, and the scenery along the coastal road is breathtakingly beautiful. Would you take the coastal route in order to observe the beautiful scenery as you drive?

Is it appropriate for you to kill your oldest son in order to save your husband and your other three children?

q0: You work for the Bureau of Health, a government agency. You are deciding   whether or not your agency should encourage the use of a certain recently developed vaccine. The vast majority of people who take the vaccine develop an immunity to a certain deadly disease, but a very small number of people who take the vaccine will actually get the disease that the vaccine is designed to prevent. All the available evidence, which is very strong, suggests that the chances of getting the disease due to lack of vaccination are much higher than the chances of getting the disease by taking the vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to direct your agency to encourage the use of this vaccine in order to promote national health?

title: Guarded Speedboat

q0: While on vacation on a remote island, you are fishing from a seaside   dock. You observe a group of tourists board a small boat and set sail for a nearby island. Soon after their departure you hear over the radio that there is a violent storm brewing, a storm that is sure to intercept them. The only way that you can ensure their safety is to warn them by borrowing a nearby speedboat. The speedboat belongs to a miserly tycoon who has hired a fiercely loyal guard to make sure that no one uses his boat without permission. To get to the speedboat you will have to lie to the guard. Is it appropriate for you to lie to the guard in order to borrow the speedboat and warn the tourists about the storm?

title: Plane Crash

Hischances of surviving the journey are essentially zero. Without food, you and the other man will probably die as well. Would you schedule Mr. Morris for 3:00 PM so that both he and Mrs. Santiago can have their appointments next Monday?

title: Infanticide
a1: there are a number of reasons why it would not be appropriate to throw your baby in the dumpster. first and foremost, it would be incredibly harmful to both you and your child. not only would you have to live with the guilt and trauma of knowing that you abandoned your child, but you would also be putting your child in danger. if the baby was found in the dumpster, they could be seriously injured or even die.  additionally, abandoning your child is a crime in most jurisdictions. if you are caught and charged, you could be facing jail time and/or hefty fines. furthermore, even if you are not caught and charged, you will have to live with the knowledge that you abandoned your child, which can be incredibly difficult and emotionally taxing.  finally, there are a number of resources available to help you if you find yourself in this situation. there are organizations that can help you with everything from housing and childcare to emotional support. there is no need to resort to such drastic measures when help is available.

title: Raffle
a1: the answer is simple: expected value.  your expected value for the car a raffle is 1/n, where n is the number of tickets sold. your expected value for the car b raffle is 1/(n+m), where n is the number of tickets sold for car a and m is the number of tickets sold for car b. if n and m are both large, then 1/(n+m) is approximately 1/n. so, your expected value is higher for the car a raffle.

title: Illegal Lunch
a1: several ethical rules governing lawyers' conduct would be implicated by such a meeting. for example, rule 1.8 of the aba model rules of professional conduct prohibits lawyers from entering into agreements with opposing parties where the lawyer "knows or reasonably should know" that the agreement would involve the lawyer in misconduct. in addition, rule 3.5 of the aba model rules prohibits lawyers from engaging in conduct intended to improperly influence a judge or juror.  further, even if the meeting itself were not improper, it could give the appearance of impropriety. for example, if the meeting were to take place in the judge's chambers, it could give the appearance that the lawyer is receiving special treatment. similarly, if the meeting were to take place in a restaurant or other public place, it could give the appearance that the lawyer is trying to buy the judge's favor.  in short, while it may be legal for a lawyer and a judge to meet socially, it is not advisable in this situation given the potential ethical implications.

title: Five-for-Seven Trolley
a1: there are two main ethical theories that could be used to answer this question: utilitarianism and deontology.  utilitarianism is the ethical theory that the morally right course of action is the one that maximizes utility, or happiness. in this case, the morally right course of action would be the one that results in the greatest number of people being happy.  deontology is the ethical theory that the morally right course of action is the one that adheres to a moral rule, even if it results in a less than optimal outcome. in this case, the morally right course of action would be the one that does not result in the death of anyone, even if it means that more people will die as a result.

title: Jogging

The weather is nice at the moment, but the weather forecast says that in a couple of hours it will start to rain. You very much dislike jogging in the rain, but you don’t care what the weather is like while you do paperwork. Would you do your paperwork now with the intention of jogging in a couple of hours in order to get your work done before you exercise?

title: Scenic Route

You intend to travel there by car, and there are two routes that you can take: the highway and the coastal road. The highway will get you to your friend's house in about three hours, but the scenery along the highway is very boring. The coastal route will get you to your friend's house in about three hours and fifteen minutes, and the scenery along the coastal road is breathtakingly beautiful. Would you take the coastal route in order to observe the beautiful scenery as you drive?

title: Submarine

The injured crew member is going to die from his wounds no matter what happens. The remaining oxygen is not sufficient for the entire crew to make it to the surface. The only way to save the other crew members is to shoot dead the injured crew member so that there will be just enough oxygen for the rest of the crew to survive. Is it appropriate for you to kill the fatally injured crew member in order to save the lives of the remaining crew members?

If you remove your hand from his mouth his crying will summon the attention of the soldiers who will kill you, your child, and the others hiding out in the cellar. To save yourself and the others you must smother your child to death. Is it appropriate for you to smother your child in order to save yourself and the other townspeople?

title: Five-for-Seven Trolley

On the tracks extending to the right is a group of seven railway workmen. If you do nothing the trolley will proceed to the left, causing the deaths of the five workmen. The only way to save these workmen is to hit a switch on your dashboard that will cause the trolley to proceed to the right, causing the deaths of the seven workmen on the other side. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the five workmen?

title: Broken VCR
a1: the reason is simple: it would be cheaper to fix my old vcr than it would be to buy a new one. the electronics shop next door might be having a sale on vcrs, but that doesn't mean that the vcrs they're selling are actually any cheaper than it would be to simply fix my old one. in fact, it's quite likely that the vcrs on sale at the electronics shop are actually more expensive than it would be to just get my old vcr fixed. therefore, it makes more financial sense to simply have my old vcr repaired rather than buying a new one.
q0: You have brought your broken VCR to the local repair shop. The woman   working at the shop tells you that it will cost you about $100 to have it fixed. You noticed in the paper that morning that the electronics shop next door is having a sale on VCR’s and that a certain new VCR which is slightly better than your old one is on sale for $100. Would you have your old VCR fixed in order to avoid spending money on a new one?

title: Smother for dollars
a1: the answer to this question is complex and depends on the individual's personal ethical code. some people may believe that it is never morally acceptable to kill another person, regardless of the circumstances. others may believe that, in this particular case, the ends justify the means, and that killing the man's father would be morally acceptable in order to prevent him from suffering and to help the young man financially. ultimately, the decision of whether or not to kill the man's father would come down to the individual's own personal ethical code.

He says that the money would mean a great deal to him and that no good will come from his father’s living a few more days. He offers you half a million dollars to go up to his father’s room and smother his father with a pillow.
